DRM100Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM100Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: An introduction to performance practice with an emphasis on the historical development and contemporary work of playwrights, actors, and directors.  Key theorists, practitioners, and schools will be introduced and students will analyze them through rigorous hands-on, experiential work. This course combines weekly two-hour lectures with one-hour tutorials.
DRM100Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions:
L0101 students will be assigned into a tutorial section that will be held once a week. Tutorials will be set during the already scheduled class time.

The L3001 section is limited to TYP (transitional year programme) students.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

DRM101Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM101Y1-Y-20169.courseTitle: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM101Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: A broad introduction to the canon of Western drama, the principles of theatre history as well as key artistic movements and notions of arts criticism through a range of dramatic texts, artistic movements, and performance practices, with particular reference to the relationship between dramatic texts and their larger contexts.  This course combines weekly two-hour lectures with one-hour tutorials.
DRM101Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions: Students will be assigned into a tutorial section on Portal that will be held once a week. Tutorials will be set during the already scheduled class time.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

DRM200Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM200Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: Emphasis is initially placed on ensemble, non-verbal, and improvisational work. Students proceed to the application of their acquired skills to scripted material. Students may apply in their first or second year of University. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round of auditions; August 3rd for the second round. See Audition Guidelines for information on how to apply.
DRM200Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite: An audition in April or in August. Students can apply directly out of high school.
DRM200Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions:
Selection is based on an audition. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists.
Apply online by March 10th for a first round April audition or by August 3rd for the second round audition held in late August. Student can apply straight out of high school: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM220Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM220Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: An intensive study of a range of historical and cross-cultural dramatic and performance texts and practices that contextualize theatre and performance more broadly within the social, political, and cultural parameters in which they take place. Theatre history is necessarily inextricable from world history and this course considers the many ways theatre and performance interact with the globalized world.

DRM228H1-F-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM228H1-F-20169.courseDescription: A hands-on study of the craft of dramatic writing. The class examines the basic elements of playwriting such as plot, structure, theme, character, dialogue, setting, with an emphasis on story-making. Attention is given to the development of students own work through written assignments and in-class exercises. See Portfolio Guidelines for information on how to apply.
DRM228H1-F-20169.prerequisite: A portfolio of writing samples due on August 3rd. Students can apply directly out of high school.
DRM228H1-F-20169.webTimetableInstructions: Admission is based on a portfolio submission in August. Apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login  Selection is based on an audition. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM230Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM230Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: An introduction to the shifting landscapes of European theatre theory, history and practice in the late 19th century and their repercussions throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. The course focuses on the developments of modern and postdramatic theatre. It also includes critical analysis of the annual Drama Mainstage production and current Canadian theatre.

DRM254Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM254Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: A practical introduction to various areas of theatre production and design. Working extensively in the Helen Gardiner Phelan Playhouse, the students form the core of the production team for Drama productions. The Application Deadline
DRM254Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite:
'sans-serif'; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-theme-font: major-latin; mso-ansi-language: EN-US;"> is March 10th for an interview in April.

"
DRM254Y1-Y-20169.corequisite: An interview in April or in August. Students can apply directly out of high school.
DRM254Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions:
Apply online by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login

There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability.Selection is based on an audition. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM300Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM300Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: Building upon the work of DRM200Y1
DRM300Y1-Y-20169.recommendedPreparation: and the development of ensemble work with an intensive focus on voice and movement practices. The
DRM300Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions: For more information on how to enrol, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM302H1-S-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM302H1-S-20169.courseDescription: An introduction to major concepts and artistic practices in directing. The course focuses on different styles, ideas, and goals of theatre directors in their relations to actors, audiences, and broad cultural and political contexts. A major component will be the practical application of basic directing techniques.
DRM302H1-S-20169.corequisite: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or any course from Group A.
DRM302H1-S-20169.webTimetableInstructions: There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability.

DRM303H1-F-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM303H1-F-20169.courseDescription: An examination of the major writers who have influenced the art of the actor in the twentieth century, with a focus on theories of actor training and the preparation for performance, the ways in which audiences assess acting as an art form, and the rise of the actor as an artist of equal status in North American and European theatre. Writers include Konstantin Stanislavsky, his followers and interpreters in America (including the Actors Studio and Lee Strasberg), along with alternatives to his 'System,' including Expressionism, Epic Theatre and the teachings of Michael Chekhov.

DRM328H1-S-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM328H1-S-20169.courseDescription:
A continuation of DRM228H1, concentrating on the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own work through written assignments, in-class exercises, and the final public presentation. See Portfolio Guidelines for information on how to apply.

"
DRM328H1-S-20169.prerequisite: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1; DRM228H1; and permission of the Centre. See online application for details.
DRM328H1-S-20169.webTimetableInstructions: Admission is based on a portfolio submission in November. Apply online: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM331H1-S-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM331H1-S-20169.courseDescription: Study of dramaturgical theory and of interpretations of the dramaturge's function in the theatre. Using examples from Canada and beyond, students apply this knowledge to theatre practice.

DRM342H1-S-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM342H1-S-20169.courseDescription: The turn of the 21st century advanced a social, political, and aesthetic shift reminiscent of that during the post-Industrial Revolution/pre-WWII epoch that launched the historical avant-garde.  This class, while exploring significant artistic and sociopolitical developments of the historical avant-garde, will primarily concentrate on the experimental theatre and performance of the past 15 years—a contemporary avant-garde that “hinge[s] on a networked spatiality, rather than on linear teleology” and reflects a growing collective investment on part of audiences and artists alike in the work of a work of art.

DRM354Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM354Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: Building on the work of DRM254Y1, students will continue their study of technical skills including lighting, sound, projections, stage management, and set construction, while also engaged in a detailed exploration of historical and contemporary theatrical stage and costume design. Working extensively in the Helen Gardiner Phelan Playhouse, the students form the core of the production team for Drama productions. The Application Deadline
DRM354Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite:
'sans-serif'; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-theme-font: major-latin; mso-ansi-language: EN-US;"> is March 10th. 

"
DRM354Y1-Y-20169.corequisite: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1, DRM254Y1, and permission of the Centre. See online application for details.
DRM354Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions: There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability.

DRM366H1-F-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM366H1-F-20169.courseDescription: Since the 1960s, actors, directors, and writers have been architects of Canadian identity. This course will study the history of Canadian theatre, with an emphasis on how Canadian playwrights and creators have been engaged with social and political issues. A survey of post-colonial theatre, cultural diversity, and gender politics on the Canadian stage.
DRM366H1-F-20169.prerequisite: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1 or a Canadian Studies Major/Specialist
DRM366H1-F-20169.recommendedPreparation: For Drama Majors and Specialists: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1

DRM375H1-F-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM375H1-F-20169.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected performance disciplines, styles, and genres within their historical and critical context. Content may vary depending on instructor.  Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office or check the website for more details.
DRM375H1-F-20169.prerequisite: DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1; DRM200Y1. Additional prerequisites may vary from year to year.
DRM375H1-F-20169.webTimetableInstructions: Must take DRM300Y1 as a pre or co-requisite. Enrol in DRM300Y at Dept.

DRM376H1-S-20169.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected performance disciplines, styles, and genres within their historical and critical context. Content may vary depending on instructor.  Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office or check the website for more details.

DRM387H1-S-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM387H1-S-20169.courseTitle: Special Topics in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM387H1-S-20169.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected issues in drama, theatre and performance studies. Content may vary depending on instructor and is counted towards Group A .  Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office and check the website for more details.

LEC-5101.subtitle: The History of Gender in Performance

DRM390Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM390Y1-Y-20169.courseTitle: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM390Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: A scholarly project at the 300 level proposed by the individual student in conversation with a member of faculty who is willing to act as supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
DRM390Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite: CGPA 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; 10 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.

DRM400Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM400Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: An in-depth study of devising theatre in a group context. This course offers an intensive exploration of the history and practice of devised theatre within the late 20th and early 21st centuries that will culminate in a number of in-class and public performances. This course is open to acting, directing, playwriting, and production and design students. The Application Deadline

DRM402H1-F-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM402H1-F-20169.courseDescription: An exploration of advanced directing for the theatre. The class is centered on student directed productions, which are publically presented at the end of term. Emphasis is placed on the development of strong central concepts and realizing the production with imagination, collaboration and creativity. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. The Application Deadline

DRM403Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM403Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: This course, taught each year by a different visiting professional theatre director, offers upper-level theatre and performance studies students the opportunity to explore acting in a full-length production. Plays are selected to challenge students in a variety of diverse ways, exposing them to a full spectrum of theatre and performance genres and possibilities. The Application Deadline

DRM411H1-Y-20169.courseDescription: Advanced movement training to refine the skills and concepts developed thus far in DRM200Y1 and DRM300Y1, focusing on performance.  Techniques of personal physical awareness, movement as a tool for discovery in acting processes, movement as communication in performance, ensemble work, and movement generation are studied. DRM428H1-S-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM428H1-S-20169.courseDescription:
A continuation of DRM328H1, concentrating upon the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on advanced style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own longer work through in-class exercises, one major written assignment, and the final public presentation. See Portfolio Guidelines for information on how to apply.

"
DRM428H1-S-20169.prerequisite: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1, DRM328H1 and a portfolio of writing samples due in November.
DRM428H1-S-20169.webTimetableInstructions: There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM454H1-F-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM454H1-F-20169.courseDescription: Continues the exploration of design and production techniques. Students are given an opportunity to use their knowledge and skills from previous production courses on an advanced level. Students are expected to participate in Drama Centre productions in senior creative and leadership roles. Focus also includes the integration of digital technology into theatrical performance.
DRM454H1-F-20169.prerequisite: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM254Y1 and DRM354Y1
DRM454H1-F-20169.webTimetableInstructions: There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM485Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM485Y1-Y-20169.courseTitle: Senior Seminar: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies Thesis
DRM485Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: Research thesis, emphasizing topics and methods used in drama, theatre and performance studies. Students must obtain permission from the instructor by submitting a research project proposal. The project may engage creative practice, but the thesis itself will be a critical, written work engaging the research and dramaturgy involved in the performance or artwork. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. . Application Deadline is April 11th.
DRM485Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite: Minimum CGPA of 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; 14 FCE, Specialist or Major in Drama and a research project proposal.
DRM485Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions: Apply online in April: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

LEC-0101.subtitle: Thesis
LEC-0101.meetingStatusNotes: Tuesdays 15:00-18:00 will take place in Media Commons Room 1

DRM487H1-F-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM487H1-F-20169.courseTitle: Senior Seminar in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM487H1-F-20169.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected issues in the theatre at the 400 level. Content may vary depending on instructor and therefore may be counted towards Groups A or B. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office or check the program’s website for more details.
DRM487H1-F-20169.prerequisite: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; 14 FCE, Specialist or Major in Drama and/or permission of the instructor.

DRM488H1-S-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM488H1-S-20169.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected issues in the theatre at the 400 level. Content may vary depending on instructor and therefore may be counted towards Groups A or B. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office or check the program’s website for more details.
DRM488H1-S-20169.prerequisite: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; 14 FCE, Specialist or Major in Drama and/or permission of the instructor.
DRM488H1-S-20169.webTimetableInstructions: For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.

DRM490Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM490Y1-Y-20169.courseTitle: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM490Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: A scholarly project at the 400 level proposed by the individual student in conversation with a member of faculty who is willing to act as supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
DRM490Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite: CGPA 2.7; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; 14 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.
DRM490Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions: 14 FCE, Specialist or Major in Drama; CGPA 3.0; A written proposal, signed by both student and faculty instructor, must be submitted for approval to the Program before registration by August 1st for a September start date. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.
